Description: Fragment of limestone sculpture (?): parts of the prenomen and nomen of Ramses II are deeply incised on this piece of stone. The surface of the stone is worn in parts. Traces of red paint are visible on the stone.
Curator's comments: The writing of the nomen can be compared to stela (.440) (T. G. H. James, 'Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum ' Part 9 (London, 1970), pl. 7, and C. Zivie, 'Giza au Deuxième Millénaire' (Cairo, 1976), 194, where the figure of Amun is mistakenly represented by that of a king) and Louvre B 18-19 (Zivie, op. cit., 198, pi. 14), both of which come from Giza. Bibliography: H. Vyse, 'Operations carried on at the Pyramids of Gizeh' (London, 1842), in, 109, pl. A, fig. 5; The British Museum, 'A guide to the Egyptian galleries (Sculpture)' (London, 1909), 198 (no. 718); B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' II (Part 2) (Oxford: Clarendon Press), i, 37 and 310; III (Part 2), 310; C. Zivie, 'Giza au Deuxième Millénaire' (Cairo, 1976), 199, note 2 (no. 1); K.A. Kitchen, 'Ramesside Inscriptions' Vol. 7 (Oxford: Blackwell Press), 46.
Bibliographic references: Bierbrier 1982 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 10. (pl.21)
Condition: Fair (incomplete). The Surface is worn in parts.
